wb!
I should probably also mention this'll be a slow-going project.  I -kinda- don't want to release it before Rusty Seas, lest people get the impression I've been slacking/getting distracted.
I know I haven't been, but in the grand scheme very few people watch these streams. :P
that's okay.
aww but that just make each of us more valuable and we can have a deeper meaning of ur work
but on the other hand, is it really that bad to just make something like this as a palette cleanser from Rusty Seas to help with creativity?
Oyah, I'm just saying that if I get it done well before Rusty Seas is finished, I might hold it for a more opportune time.
Especially since this will be an 'advancement' in my programming skills, and I don't want to create false expectations for the game where I was still learning.
wait is that idea for a nymph game you had years ago actually happening?
No no, I'm saying that my programming skills in this little interactive thing will be much cleaner and more developed than in Rusty Seas.
And I don't want to make people think there will be more animated stuff like Nymph here in Rusty Seas, because that game has enough going on already.

You would think I'd have an easy time at some point with this boss fight, but at this rate I'll be surprised if I finish this one by the end of July.
Mechanically, this is probably the most complicated fight, though, right?
Yah, but also it's fucking up in new ways I've never had to deal with before.
Like, when Bernadette hits the ground, she switches to a Broadrim sprite.  I have no fucking idea how that happens.
That usually only happens if I declare a sprite using a variable that isn't actually pointing at a sprite.  IE: I fed it a number, so it goes down the list and picks a sprite assigned to that number.
But the variable it's pulling from DOES point at a sprite.
... so she DOES transition
huhe
Ok, I think I figured it out.
It requires declaring even more variables.
And now the thing I meant to do doesn't even proc.  So it's back to the drawing board and possibly creating more new objects with their own whole set of variables.
This is now actually too much for me to figure out.
I'm gonna visit the thinking throne while I try to piece this all together.

Now I need to figure out why the kats aren't doing their lowering animation.
Don't tell me I need to make yet another object to have the kats lower properly.
So I got it fixed somehow, and I don't like it.
I have a situation where y=300, and I tell a variable to be 300 by saying variable=y, but that doesn't work.
But if I hard code in variable=300, it works.
It's hard to articulate, but basically doing it the latter way is bad practice because doing code like that makes it much harder to fix in the future.
But this is prrrobably an isolated circumstance, since this boss fight is so funky, right?
I guess.  Again, it works, but I don't like it. :P
it's bad practice because you should be naming your constants
>situation
Hello hello how we be

And at this point I don't have the luxury of time to make sane coding, so I just have to do what works now.
sounds like either a scope problem or a make problem
i.e. either it's reading a copy of the variable that is 0, or the thing's y variable isn't being set correctly
Well, I only set the y in the preceding line, so I give up.
And the Y works fine otherwise, so fuck it.
Like I'm sure somewhere there's a thing I can fix to make it work sane, but again, it would involve a day of trawling through the spaghetti to make it work.
I can make the code good, or I can make the code finished, but there's no way I'm having both. :P
can't tell more without knowing both the language and the code
And that would entail a week of telling both how GMS works and the arcane way I coded my own game. :P
But definitely next time I do a game approaching anywhere near the scope of Rusty Seas, I'm paying someone else to do all the coding, or I'm using GMS's baked in physics. :P
Everyone says not to use them, but in using them I banged out Holly-Day Ice-Spionage in less than two weeks where it would have taken me maybe half a year to code in all the interactions.
Anyboo, I don't even remember where I was.
And I think I'm sufficiently hungry that I'm just getting cranky.
So I'm gonna close the stream for a bit so I can handle food and move around a little, but I'll be back!
Me, a man with a problem, thinking to myself "I know exactly how I'd handle this in RPG Maker"
the language guide is annoying
the superficial scope shenanigans shouldn't apply, since local variables are declared explicitly
but if you're using instance identifier, there can in fact be shenanigans in that object_id.variable will write to all `object_id` instances, but read from only the first one
(i.e. spawn(mob, 0, 0), spawn(mob, 0, 300), show_message(mob.y)` will return 0)
